howToTalk.video_title: How To Talk With Your Child
howToTalk.accessibilityLabel: Video on how how to talk with your child
howToTalk.accessabilityHint: Video on how how to talk with your child
howToTalk.video_subtitle_1: It's not always easy to know how to talk with your child.
howToTalk.video_subtitle_2: Here are some tips to help.
howToTalk.subtitle: After something scary like an injury, it is not always easy to know how to talk with your child about it, and how best to help.
howToTalk.title_1: Here are some things to help you when talking about trauma with your child:
howToTalk.subtip_12_a: - Look for opportunities to hear how your child is doing.
howToTalk.subtip_12_b: - Choose a time and a place where you both feel comfortable - think about when and where your child tends to talk most openly.
howToTalk.tip_13: 3. Ask your child direct questions. 'How are you doing with all of this?'
howToTalk.tip_14: 4. Listen carefully to what your child has to say to you.
howToTalk.subtip_14_a: - Wait until your child finishes before jumping in.
howToTalk.subtip_14_b: - Repeat back what you heard in your own words to be sure you understood.
howToTalk.subtip_14_c: - Try to hold off giving advice until you have a good understanding of what your child is going through. What's been most upsetting to her? How is she feeling now?
howToTalk.subtip_21: - You can give your child a chance to work out his thoughts and feelings by saying them out loud to you.
howToTalk.tip_22: 2. Answer your child’s questions as honestly as you can.
howToTalk.subtip_22: - Keep in mind their age and what they are able to understand.
howToTalk.tip_23: 3. Help your child find words for strong feelings.
howToTalk.subtip_23: - Describing and understanding his reactions is a first step to dealing with them.
howToTalk.tip_24: 4. Share your own experiences within limits.
howToTalk.subtip_24_a: - Be a model for using good coping skills.
howToTalk.subtip_24_b: - Remember not to burden your child with your own worries. Turn to other adults you trust if you need a listening ear.
howToTalk.title_3: What if my child does not want to talk?
howToTalk.tip_31: 1. Be patient. Your child may not be ready to talk at the same time you are.
howToTalk.tip_32: 2. Do not force the issue. Do not try to force your child to talk. Some people like to think about things for a while first.
howToTalk.tip_33: 3. Encourage other ways of expressing thoughts and feelings. Your child can draw a picture, write a story, or keep a diary or journal.
howToTalk.tip_34: 4. Help your child stay connected with friends and adults you both trust, so you will know they have people to talk with when they are ready.
howToTalk.tip_35: 5. Some reactions are not said in words.
howToTalk.subtip_35_a: - Even without words, you can try to be aware of your child’s reactions.
howToTalk.subtip_35_b: - Think about how you can usually tell how your child is feeling - you might see changes in behavior, facial expressions, or body language.
howToTalk.subtip_41: - As you think about how to help your child, try to separate what you are feeling from what your child is experiencing and what they need.
howToTalk.tip_42: 2. Make sure your own feelings do not get in the way.
howToTalk.subtip_42: If talking with your child is upsetting to you, do your best to stay calm and collected during the conversation and be sure to get support for yourself.

quickTips.cardTitle: 6 quick tips to help you and your child when overcoming a traumatic injury.
quickTips.accessabilityLabelPic: Photo of a mother speaking to her child.
quickTips.tip_one: 1. Let your child know that they are safe.
quickTips.tip_two: 2. Allow children to talk about their feelings, and their worries, if they want to.
quickTips.tip_four: 4. Increase time with family and friends.
quickTips.tip_five: 5. Take time to deal with your own feelings.
quickTips.tip_six: 6. Keep in mind people in the same family can react in different ways.
quickTips.desc_one: In the first days and weeks following an injury many children fear that something bad might happen to them again. Let your child know that they are safe now. Give them extra hugs, even your teens. Younger children may need more cuddle time.
quickTips.desc_two: Let your child know that it is OK to feel a little upset; many children feel upset, worried, or confused after getting hurt. Allow your child to talk about their feelings if they want to. If they do not want to talk, stress coping strategies for kids can include writing a story or drawing a picture.
quickTips.desc_three: It is important to help your child get plenty of sleep, eat regular meals, and keep up with schoolwork. Encourage your child to go back to spending time with friends. If the injury gets in the way of things s/he used to do – talk with your doctor about what your child can do, and be creative in figuring out how to get your child back to SOME normal activities.
quickTips.desc_four: Children who get support from family and friends seem to do better in recovering after upsetting events. Try reading together, playing sports or games, or watching movies together.
quickTips.desc_five: In addition to all the things you do to help your child, it’s important to remember to take good care of yourself. It will be harder to help your child if you are really worried, upset or overwhelmed. Talk about your feelings with other adults, such as family, friends, clergy, your doctor or a counselor.
quickTips.desc_six: Remember, your child's feelings and worries about the injury might be different from yours. Brothers and sisters can feel upset too. An important way that parents can help is to pay special attention to how your child's responses might be different from yours. Those are the situations where it can be harder to know how to help.

dealWithWorries.accessibilityLabel: Video on dealing with new fears and worries
dealWithWorries.accessabilityHint: Video on dealing with new fears and worries
dealWithWorries.video_subtitle_2: Watch the video and read below to learn more about these symptoms.
dealWithWorries.q1_p1: When something scary happens, we often learn to treat things connected to it as if they were danger signals. The next time something reminds us of what happened, our body reacts as if we were in danger, even if we are safe.
dealWithWorries.q1_p2: A trauma reminder can be anything – a place or a person, a sight or a sound, or even a smell. It might be something you hardly notice, till the scared feelings come flooding back.
dealWithWorries.q2: How do we get over new fears - dealing with emotional triggers?
dealWithWorries.q2_p1: In managing emotional triggers, it can really help to face reminders over and over, in the course of normal life. We can feel very anxious at first, but each time we experience a trauma reminder and hang in there long enough to know that it does not lead to danger, the scared feelings tend to get weaker.
dealWithWorries.q2_p2: It is natural for your child to want to stay away from things that remind and upset him. But too much avoidance can get in the way of the natural recovery process, and make it harder to get over feeling scared.
dealWithWorries.q2_p3: As a parent, you play an important role in helping your child face new fears without getting stuck in avoidance.
dealWithWorries.q3: How can parents tell if fears or worries are really a problem?
dealWithWorries.q3_p1: Ask yourself: Does feeling afraid or nervous stop your child from getting back to normal safe activities? Or stop him from enjoying things even if he manages to do them?
dealWithWorries.q3_p2: If so, you can help your child deal with new fears and worries before they become a bigger problem.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip1: 1. Help your child make changes that really do help keep him safe.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip1_bullet: - Like wearing a helmet, crossing the street carefully, or telling you where he is going.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip2: 2. Be a 'reality check' for your child.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip2_bullet: - If your child is nervous about doing something, talk together and help her figure out: 'Is this really helping me stay safe?' OR 'Am I avoiding it just so I will not feel nervous?'
dealWithWorries.q4_tip3: 3. Help your child understand 'trauma reminders' emotional triggers and avoidance.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip3_bullet: - Sometimes kids need help to figure out what makes them feel scared or nervous.
dealWithWorries.q4_tip4_bullet: - Help him keep doing those safe things that make him nervous -- and praise his courage when he does!
dealWithWorries.q4_tip5_bullet1: - Ask yourself: Do my worries stop me from letting my child do things he really should be allowed to do?
dealWithWorries.q4_tip5_bullet2: - Use a trusted friend or family member as a “reality check” for yourself – to help you sort through your worries about your child’s safety.
dealWithWorries.q5_p1: If you are not sure whether your child's worries or fears are realistic, or how to encourage your child to face things that he is avoiding, get some help.
dealWithWorries.q5_p2: Talk with your family doctor, school counselor, or someone else you trust, or seek a counselor who can help you and your child in managing emotional triggers and with traumatic stress reactions.

healthcareTeam.cardTitle: It is important to work as a team.
healthcareTeam.accessibilityLabel: Photo of doctor and male patient looking at x-ray
healthcareTeam.accessabilityHint: Photo of doctor and male patient looking at x-ray
healthcareTeam.MAIN_TITLE: How To Work With Your Child's Healthcare Team
healthcareTeam.main_Paragraph_1: You have the very important job of making sure your child gets the best medical care for his physical injuries. You are also the best person to monitor how your child is coping, and when some extra help might be needed.
healthcareTeam.main_Paragraph_2: In the first few days after an injury, many kids (and parents) feel a little upset, jumpy or worried, and can use a little extra support from family and friends.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_p1: Being in the Emergency Department can be a scary and stressful experience for injured children and their parents. Parents have many worries and questions and it can sometimes be difficult to get all of the answers right away. Communicating well and often with the ED medical team about your child will help them provide your child with the best possible treatment. It can also help you play a more active role in your child's care.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b1: - Don't be afraid to ask questions. If you don't understand the answer, let the medical team know and ask, again.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b2: - Stay with your child as much as possible. Ask permission to be with your child during medical tests and procedures, if you want to be.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b3: - Be sure to let the medical team know of any pre-existing medical conditions, other special needs and fears, and allergies your child has, as well as whatever you can tell them about how the injury happened.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b4: - You are your child's most important advocate – ask how you can get involved in your child's care and when you can make decisions about treatment.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b5: - Make sure to be an advocate for your child. For example, if your child is in pain, make sure to let your child's care team know.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t1_b6: - Emergency care takes a lot of patience. You may get frustrated that other children are seen before your child, but this is likely because the staff has to make sure that the sickest patients are seen first.
healthcareTeam.CH1_TITLE_2: Tips for supporting your child in the Emergency Department
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t2_n1: 1. You are the best person to help your child. Be calm and reassuring. Hold his hand; distract him with a story or game, etc. If needed, set rules and limits like you would at home.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t2_n2: 2. Help your child understand what is happening. Make sure that the healthcare team explains things in a way your child can understand. Be honest but reassuring about what will happen. ('This will hurt now, but it will help you get better.')
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t2_n3: 3. Allow your child to talk about worries or feelings. Encourage your child's healthcare team to talk with your child directly. As much as possible, let your child answer for himself. Do not force your child to talk, but be there to listen when he is ready.
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t2_n4: 4. Take care of yourself. Get support for yourself when you are worried and upset. Remember to eat and sleep!
healthcareTeam.Ch1_t2_n5: 5. Ask for help from family and friends. Once your child has been discharged and you have returned home, come back to this website for more information on ways parents can help their kids.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_p1: Aside from the injury itself, there are things about just being in the hospital that can be traumatic for children and parents.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n1: 1. Don't be afraid to ask questions. Some parents keep a pad of paper to write down their questions. This way, when the health care team comes to examine your child, you will be prepared. If you don't understand the answer, let the medical team know and ask, again. Ask your doctor to write down the name of your child's injuries.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n2: 2. Stay overnight with your child, if possible. Ask permission to be with your child during medical tests and procedures, if you want to be.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n3: 3. Be sure to let the medical team know of any pre-existing medical conditions, other special needs and fears, and allergies your child has, as well as whatever you can tell them about how the injury happened.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n4: 4. You are your child's most important advocate – ask how you can get involved in your child's care and when you can make decisions about treatment. Let your health care team know if your child is in pain.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n5: 5. Take time for yourself. It is important to take breaks as often as you need them. Take a shower; make some phone calls; get something to eat or drink; or go to the chapel to think or cry – whatever it is that you need for yourself. After your break, you will feel better able to support your child. Let your child's health care team know when you leave your child's bedside and when you return.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n6: 6. Make of list of what other people can do to help you. When people call and offer support, you will have something concrete to ask. You do not need to do it all.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n7: 7. Ask the health care team to help you schedule all of your outpatient visits before you leave the hospital.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n8: 8. Make sure that your child's pain is under control before you leave the hospital.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n9: 9. Make sure that you have a good phone number to call if you have questions when you return home.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t1_n10: 10. Ask for copies of your child's x-rays, CT scans, or MRI scans.
healthcareTeam.CH2_TITLE_2: Tips for supporting your child in the hospital.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n1: 1. You are the best person to help your child.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n3: 3. Help your child understand what is happening.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n4: 4. Make sure that you have a good phone number to call if you have questions when you return home.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n6: 6. Help your child see the staff as helpers.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n7: 7. Stay with your child (or have a family member or friend stay) as much as possible.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t2_n9: 9. Bring things from home to make your child comfortable – bath robe, toys, and favorite books.
healthcareTeam.CH2_TITLE_3: Tips for supporting your teen in the hospital.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n2: 2. Include your teen in medical discussions when possible.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n3: 3. Encourage your child's health care team to talk with your teen directly and let him answer his own questions. He might want to talk alone with the doctors.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n4: 4. Remember that teens can be self-conscious, and they may worry about how they will look and fit in with others, and about their privacy.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n5: 5. Help your teen stay connected with old friends, as well as make new friends in the hospital.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n6: 6. Bring things from home to make your child comfortable – bath robe, music, and magazines.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t3_n7: 7. Call your child's school to let them know what has happened.
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t4_p1: Most hospitals have staff who is experienced with helping other parents and caregivers in your situation. If you are upset, have questions about how to help your child, or just need to talk, please seek out someone at the hospital who is available to assist you and your family. This may be a:
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t4_b3: - Or a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or psychiatrist
healthcareTeam.Ch2_t4_p2: Once your child has been discharged and you have returned home, come back to this website for more information on ways parents can help their kids.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_p1: After your child is discharged from the Emergency Department or Hospital, she will need to follow up with her doctor and possibly other healthcare professionals to make sure that she is healing well. It would be helpful to go through the rest of this website before going to the doctor. This site will allow you to rate your child's reactions and create a report to share with your doctor.
healthcareTeam.CH3_TITLE_1: Working with the Healthcare Team AFTER the Hospital
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n1: 1. Make sure to keep all of your appointments even if your child is feeling better.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n2: 2. Many parents like to keep all of their child's injury information together in a binder or folder. In the front of the binder, keep a sheet with your child's diagnosis and all of the medicines that your child is taking. Keep a calendar with all of the appointments.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n3: 3. Keep a pad of paper around the house to write down questions for your doctor or other healthcare professional as you think of them. Encourage your child to keep track of her questions, too.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n4: 4. You are your child's most important advocate – ask how you can get involved in your child's care and when you can make decisions about treatment. Let your health care team know if your child is in pain or is having other reactions that concern you or your child.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n5: 5. Make sure that you have a good phone number to call if you have questions. Also, ask what you should look for and when to call.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n6: 6. Ask for a summary of every visit to take with you, if possible.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t1_n7: 7. If you find that you are missing a lot of work, you might want to look into obtaining Family Medical Leave. In 1993, the federal government passed a law that allows families to take some time to care for family members without fear of losing their job.
healthcareTeam.CH3_TITLE_2: Tips for helping your child at follow-up visits
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t2_n1: 1. Tell your child about the appointment a few days in advance. Explain the reason for the visit, using words your child can understand. Answer questions simply and honestly.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t2_n2: 2. Find out, in advance, if the visit will involve any painful or scary procedures. If so, talk with your physician about how to prepare for these procedures and if any medicine should be given, in advance.
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t2_n3: 3. Let your child know you'll be there throughout the entire appointment unless your child wants some time to talk with the physician or specialist alone. Encourage your child's physician to ask your child questions directly. Encourage your child to ask the doctors and nurses questions.
healthcareTeam.CH3_TITLE_3: At the Follow-up Visit: Resources for Families
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t3_p1: Most hospitals have staff who are experienced with helping other parents and caregivers in your situation. If you are upset, have questions about how to help your child, about financial or insurance issues, or just need to talk, please seek out someone at the hospital who is available to assist you and your family. This may be a:
healthcareTeam.Ch3_t3_b3: - Or a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or psychiatrist come back to this website for more information on ways parents can help their kids.

injuryPainCare.cardTitle: Help you and your child overcome an injury.
injuryPainCare.accessibilityLabel: Photo of a young girl walking with crutches and a nurse assisting her.
injuryPainCare.accessabilityHint: Photo of a young girl walking with crutches and a nurse assisting her.
injuryPainCare.main_Paragraph_1: This section of the website offers some general information about common injuries and tips for home management, as well as helpful hints for pain management and injury prevention.
injuryPainCare.main_Paragraph_2: Remember, your healthcare provider is the best source for information regarding your child's injury. If you have specific questions or concerns about your child's injury or treatment, please make sure to talk with your healthcare provider. If any information in this website is different from what your healthcare provider recommends, follow your healthcare provider's advice.
injuryPainCare.main_Paragraph_3: Full recovery goes beyond physical healing - learn more about your child's emotional recovery after an injury, and how you can help.
injuryPainCare.Ch1_p1: Each year, one in every four children is treated by a doctor because of an injury such as a fall from a bicycle or an animal bite. Some of these injuries are minor, but many of them are very serious.
injuryPainCare.Ch1_p2: You can’t always stop your children from getting bumps and bruises but you can reduce the chances that they’ll be seriously injured by taking safety precautions such as always buckling up in motor vehicles.
injuryPainCare.Ch1_accessabilityHint: Navigates to a website about safety tips
injuryPainCare.Ch1_p3: to find more safety tips on topics such as child passenger safety, bicycle safety, dog bites, falls, pedestrian safety, fire safety, water safety and more.
injuryPainCare.Ch2_p1: Abdominal trauma involves injury to the belly between the chest and the hips and the internal organs there – the most common injuries to organs in the belly include the small intestine, liver, spleen, pancreas, kidneys, and bladder.
injuryPainCare.Ch2_p2: Follow instructions provided by your healthcare provider (doctor or nurse practitioner). It is important that your child follow all of the special instructions given by your healthcare provider to decrease any risk of bleeding inside.
injuryPainCare.CH2_TITLE_1: Make sure to ask your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t1_b1: - How long should my child only have minimal activity or 'house arrest'? This will generally depend on the grade of injury to your child's organ or how severe it was. Your doctor will tell you what minimal activity means. It could include activities such as quiet play, reading, coloring, and watching TV. It probably means that your child will have to avoid sports for a period of time.
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t1_b2: - When can my child return to school?
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t1_b3: - When can my child start gym? contact sports? biking? or rough play?
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t1_b4: - This will also depend on the grade of injury to your child's organ or how severe it was.
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t1_b5: - What is the best number to call for emergencies during the week? On weekends?
injuryPainCare.CH2_TITLE_2: When to call your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t2_b1: - Ask your healthcare provider for specific signs and symptoms that should alert you to call them right away. They may include the following: Signs of intra-abdominal bleeding (bleeding in the belly) such as:
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t2_b4: - Blood in urine, stools (bowel movement) or vomitus (throw up)
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t2_b5: - Fever (temperature greater than 101 degrees Fahrenheit or 38.5 degrees Celsius)
injuryPainCare.Ch2_t2_b8: - Any other concerns that you may have.
injuryPainCare.CHAPTER_3_MAIN_TITLE: Taking Care of Your Child's Cast
injuryPainCare.Ch3_p1: A cast holds a broken bone in place while it heals. Casts also help to prevent or decrease muscle contractions and can help limit movement, especially after surgery.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_p2: The outside of the cast is made from one of two types of casting materials:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_b2: - Fiberglass (comes in a variety of colors)
injuryPainCare.Ch3_p3: Cotton and other synthetic materials are used to line the inside of the cast to make it soft and to provide padding around bony areas, such as the wrist or elbow.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_p4: Follow instructions provided by your healthcare provider (doctor or nurse practitioner) It is important that your child follow all of the special instructions given by your healthcare provider to make sure that the broken bone heals well.
injuryPainCare.CH3_TITLE_1: Some things that your child's healthcare provider might suggest:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b1: - Keep the cast clean and dry. Do not get it wet in the shower or tub or swimming pool. Ask your doctor how you can buy a protective sleeve if you think your child might be somewhere where his cast might get wet. Check for cracks and breaks in the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b2: - Check for rough edges. These rough edges can be padded to protect the skin from scratches.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b3: - Do not scratch the skin under the cast by inserting objects inside the cast – this can cut the skin.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b4: - If your child complains of itching, use a hairdryer placed on a cool setting to blow air under the cast. Never blow warm or hot air into the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b5: - Do not put powders or lotions inside the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b6: - Cover the cast while your child is eating to prevent food spills and crumbs from entering the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b7: - Prevent small toys or objects from being put inside the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b8: - Elevate the cast above the level of the heart to decrease swelling.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b9: - Encourage your child to move his or her fingers or toes to promote circulation.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b10: - Older children with body casts may need to use a bedpan or urinal in order to go to the bathroom.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b11: - Tips to keep body casts clean and dry and prevent skin irritation around the genital area include the following:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b12: - Use a diaper or sanitary napkin around the genital area to prevent leakage or splashing urine.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b13: - Place toilet paper inside the bedpan to prevent urine from splashing onto the cast or bed.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t1_b14: - Keep the genital area as clean and dry as possible to prevent skin irritation.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t2_b1: - Your child may need to have sponge baths until the cast is removed.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t2_b2: - How to wash your child's hair: Lay your child across a bed a place a bucket on the floor to catch the water as you shampoo. You can also get 'no-rinse' shampoo at the drug store.
injuryPainCare.CH3_TITLE_3: Make sure to ask your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b1: - How long will my child need to wear the cast?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b2: - What are the limits to my child's activity while he wears the cast?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b3: - What are the limits on my child's activity once you take off the cast?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b4: - When can my child return to school?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b5: - When can my child return to gym class? to contact sports? to biking? or to rough play?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b6: - Will my child need physical therapy?
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t3_b7: - Will this injury affect my child's growth?
injuryPainCare.CH3_TITLE_4: When to call your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_p1: Ask your healthcare provider for specific signs and symptoms that should alert you to call them right away. They may include the following:
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b1: - Your child has increasing pain and pain medicine recommended or prescribed by your healthcare provider is not helping.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b2: - You see a change in the cast; cracking, softening, drainage from the inside.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b3: - You smell a bad odor coming from the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b4: - Your child's fingers or toes are cold, blue/gray or swollen.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b5: - Your child feels numbness or tingling in the fingers or toes.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b6: - Your child cannot move his/her fingers or toes.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b8: - There is increased swelling above or below the cast.
injuryPainCare.Ch3_t4_b10: - If you have any other concerns.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_p1: For hip, leg, knee, ankle, or foot injuries, your healthcare provider may order crutches to decrease pain, speed recovery, and help with walking. Make sure that a trained healthcare professional fits your child for child-sized crutches and teaches your child how to use them.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_p2: Ask your healthcare provider for specific signs and symptoms that should alert you to call them right away. They may include the following:
injuryPainCare.Ch4_p3: Follow instructions provided by your healthcare provider (doctor or nurse practitioner) It is important that your child follow all of the special instructions given by your healthcare provider to make sure that your child heals completely. If you have any questions or concerns about the fit of your child's crutches or what should or should not do while on crutches, please contact your healthcare provider.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t1_b1: - Remind your child that crutches are not toys or weapons.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t1_b2: - Even if your child may be feeling better, make sure to use the crutches as long as your healthcare provider told you to use them. If you start putting weight on the leg too soon, you might cause a new injury or increase the recovery time.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b1: - Be very careful on slick or wet surfaces (like in the kitchen and the bathroom).
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b2: - Be careful of throw rugs that can slip. They should be removed.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b3: - Never hop around holding on to furniture; it may slide or fall.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b4: - Keep the crutches nearby so they are always in reach.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b5: - Wear low-heeled shoes (like sneakers) that will not slip off.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b6: - Be careful of ramps or slopes. It is harder to walk with crutches on ramps or slopes.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b7: - Do not remove any parts of the crutches, including the rubber tips.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t2_b8: - If they feel uncomfortable on crutches, ask someone to help. For example, someone can carry their books.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b1: - A bedside toilet may be used.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b2: - Ask teachers in school to let your child out of class a little early to avoid crowds on the stairs.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b3: - Keep the 'bad' leg up on a stool while sitting.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b4: - Carry schoolbooks in a backpack to leave both hands free and ask a friend to carry it for you, if possible.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b5: - Avoid leaning on the underarm pieces.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t3_b6: - If your child's school is more than two stories tall, ask if your child can have a key to the elevator.
injuryPainCare.CH4_TITLE_4: Make sure to ask your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b1: - How long will my child need to be on crutches?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b2: - Can my child bear any weight on his injured leg?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b3: - What are the limits to my child's activity while he is on crutches?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b4: - What are the limits on my child's activity once he is off of his crutches?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b5: - When can my child return to school?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b6: - When can my child return to gym class? to contact sports? to biking? or to rough play?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b7: - Will my child need physical therapy?
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t4_b8: - Will this injury affect my child's growth?
injuryPainCare.CH4_TITLE_5: When to call your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t5_b1: - Your child has increasing pain and pain medicine recommended or prescribed by your healthcare provider is not helping.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t5_b2: - Your child feels numbness or tingling in his arms.
injuryPainCare.Ch4_t5_b3: - If you have any other concerns.
injuryPainCare.Ch5_p1: Head injury is a broad term that describes injuries to the scalp, skull, brain, and tissue and blood vessels in the child’s head. Some head injuries are also called brain injury, or traumatic brain injury (TBI), depending on the extent of the head trauma. Concussion is the most common type of TBI.
injuryPainCare.Ch5_p2: A concussion is caused by a blow or jolt to the head or body that causes the brain to shake. The shaking can cause the brain not to work normally and can result in serious side effects. If your child hits her head, be aware of the concussion symptoms to look for, which are commonly physical (such as a headache, nausea, or dizziness), sleep-related, difficulty concentrating/remembering, or involve mood disruption.
injuryPainCare.Ch5_p3: Initial treatment for a concussion is rest, both mental and physical, which allows the brain time to heal. Every child’s injury and recovery is unique, but with guidance from a doctor, your child can slowly return to school and to play following a concussion.
injuryPainCare.Ch5_p4_part1: For comprehensive information about concussion, including how a concussion is diagnosed, prevention strategies, returning to school and play, and support resources, visit
injuryPainCare.Ch5_accessabilityHint: Navigates to a website about concussions
injuryPainCare.Ch5_click_here: Concussion Care for Kids: Minds Matter
injuryPainCare.Ch5_p4_part2: , a website developed by an interdisciplinary team of concussion experts at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_p1: Nearly everyone has pain after an injury. For most children, our research has shown that the pain will get a lot better during the first week after getting care for an injury. If the pain gets worse, make sure to talk to your child's doctor.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_p2: Follow instructions provided by your healthcare provider It is important that your child follow all of the special instructions given by your healthcare provider and takes pain medicines as your healthcare provider told you to use them. The following are general suggestions about pain.
injuryPainCare.CH6_TITLE_1: 1. How to recognize pain in your school-aged child and teen:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_child_p1: School-aged children may display different behaviors when they are in pain or uncomfortable. Your child may:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_child_b2: - Not eat or drink as much as usual
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_child_b5: - Become less active, lie quietly, or curl up in bed
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_child_b8: - Hold or protect the area of discomfort
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_teen_p1: Teens may display different behaviors when they are in pain or uncomfortable. Remember that teen athletes may not want to admit to pain if it keeps them out of sports. Your teen may:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_teen_b3: - Not eat or drink as much as usual
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_teen_b4: - Lose interest in family and friends
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t1_teen_b5: - Become less active, lie quietly, or curl up in bed
injuryPainCare.CH6_TITLE_2: 2. How to help manage your child's pain:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_p1: Make sure to use the pain medicines in the doses and at the times that your healthcare professional recommended. Keep a pain diary, recording where your child's pain is, how bad it is, when it happens, what makes it better, and what makes it worse. There are many ways, other than medicine, to comfort your child. The healthcare team can make suggestions for your child, but here are some basics for getting started.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_A: A. Create a comfortable and safe environment
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_A_b2: - Stay with your child as much as possible.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_B: B. Use gentle and firm touch to provide comfort and security
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_B_b2: - Massage your child's body in a firm, slow motion
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_C: C. Use distraction to help your school-age child focus on something other than pain. Encourage your child to:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_C_b5: - Talk about a favorite place or memory
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_C_b6: - Play a game or watch TV
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForChild_C_b7: - Do art projects, draw, or color
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_A: A. Create a comfortable and safe environment
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_A_b2: - Offer to stay with your teen
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_A_b4: - Approach your teen in a calm, comforting way.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_B: B. Use gentle and firm touch to provide comfort and security
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_B_b2: - Offer hugs or hold your teen's hand
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_C: C. Use distraction to help your teen focus on something other than pain. Encourage your teen to:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_C_b4: - Talk about a pleasant experience or memory.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_C_b5: - Play a game or watch TV
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t2_ForTeen_C_b6: - Do art projects, draw, or color
injuryPainCare.CH6_TITLE_3: 3. When to call your child's doctor
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t3_p1: Make sure to ask your healthcare provider what symptoms to look out for and whether you should call or go straight to the hospital. Some of these symptoms are:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t3_b1: - Your child has increasing pain and pain medicine recommended or prescribed by your healthcare provider is not helping.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t3_b2: - Your child has a new pain.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t3_b3: - If you have any other concerns
injuryPainCare.CH6_TITLE_4: 4. Make sure to ask your healthcare provider:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b1: - How do I keep a pain diary and what information should I record?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b2: - What is the best way to assess my child's pain, given their age or level?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b3: - What symptoms should I look for in my child? How often should I check?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b4: - What should I do if my child has a symptom you told me to watch for? Should I call the office, call 911, or go to the hospital?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b5: - Can my child return to school?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b6: - What are the limits to my child's activity?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b7: - When can my child start gym? contact sports? biking? or rough play?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b8: - Will you please call my child's school and explain how to manage my child's pain and anything else they need to know about my child?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b9: - What kind of pain can be expected and for how long?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b0: - How will the pain be controlled before, during and after any procedures?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b11: - If your child receives pain medication, learn as much as you can about the medicine from the doctor, nurse, or pharmacist. Talk to your healthcare provider about any side effects your child might have and how to help treat them.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t4_b12: - How can I manage my child's pain during therapy if my child is going to get physical therapy?
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_p1: When you bring your child in for his follow-up visits or with specialists, remember to:
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_b1: - Let your healthcare provider know if your child is still having any pain.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_b2: - Let your doctor know where the pain is, what makes it better, what makes it worse.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_b3: - Bring all of your medicines with you to all appointments.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_b4: - If you are going to another specialist, try to bring along any medical records and copies of radiographs, MRIs, and CT scans.
injuryPainCare.Ch6_t5_b5: - If your child is going to therapy, ask them to manage your child's pain.

content.definition: A superficial rub or wearing off of the skin, usually caused by a scrape or brush burn.
A superficial rub or wearing off of the skin, usually caused by a scrape or brush burn.
A dislocation occurs when extreme force is put on a joint and causes bones to come out of the joint. Dislocations can cause two or more bones to come together.

If more force is put on a bone than it can stand, it will split or break. A break of any size is called a fracture. If the broken bone punctures the skin, it is called an open fracture.  If a break is in a lot of pieces, it is called a compound fracture.

Head injury is a broad term that describes injuries to the scalp, skull, brain, and tissue and blood vessels in the child's head. Some head injuries are also called brain injury, or traumatic brain injury (TBI), depending on the extent of the head trauma. Concussion is the most common type of TBI.
A large bruise or collection of blood under the skin, producing discoloration and swelling in the area. It is usually caused by trauma.
A cut, tear, or ragged opening in the skin caused by an injury or trauma.
Injuries due to minor trauma over a long period of time, involving bone, muscles, ligaments, and/or tendons.
A deep wound or hole in the skin and deeper tissue layers caused by a sharp object such as a nail, stick, a dog’s tooth, or a piece of metal.
A partial or complete tear of a ligament (connects two bones) or tendon (connects a bone to a muscle). Sprains often affect the ankles, knees, or wrists.
An injury to a muscle or tendon. Often caused by overuse, force, or stretching.
A hairline crack in the bone that develops because of repeated or prolonged forces to the bone.

Whiplash occurs when the muscles or ligaments (soft tissue) of the neck are injured by a sudden jerking or “whipping” of the head. This type of motion stretches the muscles or ligaments of the neck beyond their normal range of motion.

A bone that links the scapula (shoulder blade) and sternum (breastbone), is situated just above the first rib on either side of the neck, and has the form of a narrow elongated S -- also called collarbone.
The skeleton of the head forming a bony case that encloses and protects the brain -- also called skull.
The top bone of the lower limb that is the longest and largest bone in the human body, extending from the hip to the knee -- also called thigh bone.
The outer and usually the smaller of the two bones of the lower limb below the knee that is the slenderest bone of the human body in proportion to its length -- also called shin bone.
The longest bone of the upper arm or forelimb extending from the shoulder to the elbow.

The kidneys are bean-shaped organs located just under the rib cage in the back, one on each side. They are responsible for filtering the by-products of our body’s metabolism from the blood and removing this waste as urine.

The liver is a large organ located under the ribcage in the right upper part of the abdomen. It is responsible for producing bile, and it plays a major role in the handling and processing of nutrients.
The lower jaw.

The bony cavity that occupies the lateral front of the skull immediately beneath the frontal bone on each side and encloses and protects the eye and its appendages -- also called eye socket, orbital cavity.
A long gland that is located behind the stomach. The pancreas secretes digestive enzymes and the hormones insulin and glucagon.
The structure below the spine and above the leg; composed of the two hip bones one on each side and in front while the sacrum and coccyx complete it behind.
The bone on the thumb side of the forearm.

The spleen is in the uppermost area of the left side of the abdomen, just under the diaphragm. It typically has attachments to the stomach, left kidney, and colon. The spleen plays a role in immunity against bacterial infections.
The tibia is the larger of two long bones in the lower leg (between the knee and ankle). Sometimes called the shin bone.
The bone on the little-finger side of the forearm that forms with the humerus at the elbow joint.
Any segment (bone or cartilage) that makes up the spinal column that encloses the spinal cord.
A pain-relieving and fever-reducing drug found in many over-the-counter medications. Sometimes called Tylenol®.
A group of drugs that kill bacteria and other organisms that cause disease.
Drugs that reduce the symptoms and signs of inflammation.

A cast holds a broken bone in place as it heals, prevents or decreases muscle contractures, or provides immobilization, especially after surgery. Casts immobilize the joint above and the joint below the area that is to be kept straight and without motion. For example, a child with a forearm fracture will have a long arm cast to immobilize the wrist and elbow joints.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) found in many over-the-counter medications, sometimes call Advil® or Motrin®.
An X-ray of all the bones of the body; often done when medical staff are looking for fractures or tumor metastasis to the bones.

content.term: Computed Tomography Scan (CT or CAT Scan)
content.definition: A diagnostic imaging procedure that uses a combination of x-rays and computer technology to produce cross sectional images (often called “slices”), both horizontally and vertically, of the body. A CT scan shows detailed images of any part of the body, including the bones, muscles, fat and organs. CT scans are more detailed than general x-rays.
Introducing a fluid into the bloodstream through a vein (usually in the patient’s forearm).
A group of operations performed with the aid of a camera placed in the abdomen or belly.
An operation of the abdomen through an incision (cut) in the skin.
Anesthetic medicine injected into the site of the operation to temporarily numb that area.
A diagnostic procedure that uses a combination of large magnets, radiofrequencies, and a computer to produce detailed images of organs and structures within the body.
A diagnostic effort or treatment that does not require entering the body or puncturing the skin.

A diagnostic imaging technique which uses high-frequency sound waves and a computer to create images of blood vessels, tissues, and organs. Ultrasounds are used to view internal organs as they function, and to assess blood flow through vessels.
A diagnostic test that uses invisible electromagnetic energy beams to produce images of internal tissues, bones and organs onto film.

content.term: Advanced Practice Nurse or Nurse Practitioner
content.definition: This nurse has advanced training, education, and knowledge in specialty areas. They work closely with the attending physician and primary nurse to help coordinate your child’s care before, during and after hospitalization.
A senior member of the hospital’s medical or surgical staff who is responsible for your child’s treatment.
Can assist families in planning for discharge to home or another healthcare facility.
Chaplain provides pastoral visitation, sacramental ministry, and support. Often times hospitals have spiritual coordinators from various faiths.
An expert doctor may be asked by your child’s attending physician to help diagnose and treat your child.
The dietitian will assess your child’s nutritional needs, make a plan to meet those needs, and assist families in choosing a healthy lifetime diet.
A physician who has completed resident training and is now training in a special field of pediatrics, surgery, or other specialty.
A nurse who supervises and manages a patient care unit/area.

The occupational therapist helps a child recover from an injury and reach their highest level of physical and social function. Occupational therapists teach patients how to perform activities of daily living such as dressing, bathing, and feeding. The therapist may help the family to make their home easier for the patient to live in and use.

A medical doctor who specializes in physical medicine and rehabilitation whose primary responsibility is the medical care of the patient. After your child is medically stable and starts the rehab program, the physiatrist coordinates the work of the health care team by directing therapy services and ordering medication, braces, wheelchair, etc.

The physical therapist helps a child recover from an injury.  He teaches patients to do as much for themselves as possible.  This involves evaluating patients’ needs and then starting exercises to increase muscle strength and joint movement.  Patients are taught how to move in bed, how to transfer from one place to another, and how to operate a wheelchair. If possible, the physical therapist may also teach patients to walk again; using whatever equipment is most helpful.
This nurse is responsible for planning and coordinating your child’s care throughout the entire hospital stay.

Licensed physicians (M.D. or D.O.) who specialize in the evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of mental disorders. Their medical and psychiatric training prepares them to provide individual, family, and group treatment.  Child psychiatrists have additional years of training in diagnosis and treatment of children and adolescents.  Psychiatrists can prescribe medications, if needed.

Licensed practitioners (Ph.D. or Psy.D.) who specialize in the evaluation, diagnosis and treatment of behavioral and emotional problems and disorders. Their training in emotional and cognitive processes, human development, and behavior change prepares them to provide individual, family, and group treatment . Child and pediatric psychologists have specialized training in the treatment of children and adolescents.
A physician who is receiving advanced training in the hospital. A resident cares under the direction of the attending physician.
A respiratory therapist will assess a patient’s breathing.  He/she provides treatment ordered by the physician and teaches the patient and family about ongoing respiratory care needs.

This professional helps adjust to illness, and can advise you about insurance, financial resources, and community agencies that can help with needs such as respite care, counseling, parent support groups, and home care.

The speech pathologist helps a child recover from an injury that makes it hard for a child to speak. She evaluates patients for cognitive and communication problems, and starts therapy as needed. Patients may have trouble saying what they want and need. They may have slurred speech from weak muscles.  The speech pathologist helps to improve this. He/she can also suggest communication tools that will help.
If you are at a teaching hospital, you may meet medical or nursing students as part of your child’s treatment. They are closely supervised by fully trained and licensed doctors or nurses.

Severe traumatic stress symptoms that develop within one month of exposure to a traumatic event or experience. ASD symptoms include dissociative symptoms (i.e. feeling emotionally numb or in a daze), re-experiencing the event (i.e. intrusive thoughts or flashbacks), avoiding things that set off feelings about the trauma, and hyperarousal (i.e. startling easily, being hyper-vigilant). Acute stress disorder is diagnosed when symptoms last for at least 2 days and get in the way of normal functioning. If symptoms last for more than 4 weeks, see posttraumatic stress disorder.

A term used to describe traumatic stress symptoms that involve wanting to stay away from people, places, or activities because they remind one of the traumatic event. Avoidance can also include strong or excessive efforts to not think about or talk about the traumatic event.

content.term: DSM-IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition)
content.definition: The official manual of mental health problems used by psychiatrists, psychologists, and other mental health providers to understand and diagnose mental health problems. Insurance companies and health care providers also use terms and definitions in this book when discussing mental health issues.
Practices, including medical and psychological treatments and therapies, which have been clearly researched and found to be supported by scientific evidence or proof.
A term used to describe traumatic stress symptoms that can include startling easily, hypervigilance, difficulties falling or staying asleep, and trouble concentrating.
Feeling “on alert” or afraid much of the time, or overly sensitive to trauma reminders and prone to interpret them as danger signals (even in safe situations).

Severe traumatic stress symptoms that develop, and persist, after exposure to a traumatic event or experience. PTSD symptoms include re-experiencing the event (i.e. via intrusive thoughts or flashbacks), avoiding things that set off feelings about the trauma, and hyperarousal (i.e. startling easily, being hypervigilant). PTSD is diagnosed when these symptoms last for more than one month, cause significant distress, and get in the way of normal life.
A term used to describe traumatic stress symptoms that include upsetting intrusive thoughts, having nightmares or flashbacks, or becoming upset or having physical reactions to trauma reminders.

In medical settings, the term “trauma” can have several different meanings. Medical professionals use “trauma” to refer to physical injury. Mental health professionals often use “trauma” to refer to an extremely frightening event or the psychological effects of experiencing such an event.
People, places, activities or other things that bring back memories of a traumatic experience. Trauma reminders can make people feel upset, fearful, or put them “on alert”.

quizMain.accessibilityLabelCont: Quiz to rate child's traumatic stress level
quizMain.accessabilityLabelPic: Image of child reacting to stress
quizMain.title: Rate your child's reactions in the quiz below.
quizMain.description: You can rate these on your own, based on what you have noticed with your child. If possible, you may want to involve your child in answering these questions with you.
quizMain.q1: 1. Thinks a lot about what happened to them
quizMain.q2: 2. Has bad dreams or nightmares since the injury
quizMain.q3: 3. Gets upset or has physical reactions (headache, stomachache, heart pounding) at reminders of what happened
quizMain.q4: 4. Doesn’t want to talk about what happened or tries to push it out of their mind
quizMain.q5: 5. Wants to stay away from people, places, or things that are reminders of what happened
quizMain.q6: 6. Afraid of something that they were not afraid of before (or a previous fear or worry seems to get worse)
quizMain.q7: 7. Not interested in usual activities, since the injury
quizMain.q8: 8. Not interested in being with people they usually like being with, since the injury
quizMain.q9: 9. Worries a lot that something else bad will happen
quizMain.q10: 10. Startles easily – for example, jumps if there is a sudden noise
quizMain.q11: 11. Seems irritable or has angry outbursts, since the injury
quizMain.q12: 12. Has trouble paying attention to things, since the injury
quizMain.q13: 13. Has trouble falling or staying asleep, since the injury
quizMain.q14: 14. Is still having pain or discomfort
quizMain.q15: 15. Has had other behavior changes since the injury
quizMain.q16: 16. Is having trouble with returning to school or other activities
quizMain.qt5: Concerns about how others in the family are coping
quizMain.q17: 17. Brothers or sisters are upset or worried
quizMain.q18: 18. You (parent) are stressed or worried yourself
quizMain.disclaimer1: This is not a formal medical or psychological assessment or diagnosis. If you are concerned with how you or your child is doing, please contact your doctor mental health professional, or other healthcare provider.
quizMain.disclaimer2: Please use these ratings as a basis for conversation to learn more about your patient’s response to a recent injury.
quizMain.accessibilityLabelSub: Click here to submit your results

quizResults.noAnswers: Oops! Looks like you forgot to select any answers.
quizResults.q1title: Thinks a lot about what happened to them
quizResults.q1body1: Thinking and talking about what happened, especially in the first few days and weeks, is part of how we help ourselves recover from a scary experience.
quizResults.q1body2: Do thoughts about it often pop into their mind even when they don't want them to? Does this bother them?
quizResults.q2title: Has bad dreams or nightmares since the injury
quizResults.q2body1: It's normal for kids to have bad dreams from time to time.
quizResults.q2body2: Are the nightmares worse or more frequent since the injury? Are they interfering with getting a good night’s sleep?
quizResults.q3title: Gets upset or has physical reactions at reminders of what happened
quizResults.q3body1: When something scary happens, we learn to treat things connected to it as if they were danger signals. Sights, sounds, and even smells can be reminders.
quizResults.q3body2: Do these feelings happen nearly every day? Do they make it hard for your child to relax and have fun, or to concentrate on schoolwork?
quizResults.q4title: Doesn’t want to talk about what happened or tries to push it out of their mind
quizResults.q4body1: Everyone needs to take a break sometimes from thinking about or talking about a scary experience. (And there may be times when you’re ready to talk but your child isn’t.)
quizResults.q4body2: Does your child seem to never want to think or talk about it with anyone, or does talking about it make them feel quite upset?
quizResults.q5title: Wants to stay away from people, places, or things that are reminders of what happened
quizResults.q5body1: After something scary happens, reminders of what happened can make us feel very anxious, and we might start to avoid those things.
quizResults.q5body2: Is avoiding reminders stopping your child from doing (safe) things they would otherwise be able to do, or from enjoying activities when they do manage to do them?
quizResults.q6title: Afraid of something that they were not afraid of before (or a previous fear or worry seems to get worse)
quizResults.q6body1: After something scary happens, we can become afraid of things that are reminders of what happened.
quizResults.q6body2: Are fears stopping your child from doing (safe) things they would otherwise be able to do, or from enjoying activities even when they do manage to do them?
quizResults.q7title: Not interested in usual activities, since the injury
quizResults.q7body1: One way we cope with overwhelming scary experiences is to “shut down” our emotions for a while. And kids may feel a bit down or stressed when dealing with a lot of changes after an injury.
quizResults.q7body2: Does your child seem to be not enjoying lots of things they used to like to do? Do they seem sad or withdrawn, or like their feelings are “shut down” much of the time?
quizResults.q8title: Not interested in being with people they usually like being with, since the injury
quizResults.q8body1: One way we cope with overwhelming scary experiences is to “shut down” our emotions and not feel close to other people for a while. Sometimes other people are reminders of what happened or of how things have changed.
quizResults.q8body2: Does your child seem to be having a really hard time feeling relaxed and close to friends and family they usually trust and enjoy time with?
quizResults.q9title: Worries a lot that something else bad will happen
quizResults.q9body1: Being on the lookout for danger makes sense after something scary has happened. It’s how we learn to keep ourselves safe from things that are truly dangerous.
quizResults.q9body2: Are your child’s feelings of being “on guard” for potential danger very strong? Does your child feel this way a lot of the time? Is it making it harder to get back to doing things they used to do?
quizResults.q10title: Startles easily – for example, jumps if there is a sudden noise
quizResults.q10body1: A frightening experience can trigger an exaggerated physical startle response that takes some time to go away.
quizResults.q10body2: Is your child feeling so jumpy that it’s really hard to relax? Is it affecting his/ her sleep or ability to concentrate?
quizResults.q11title: Seems irritable or has angry outbursts, since the injury
quizResults.q11body1: Stress and changes can lead to frustrations for injured kids. Feeling jumpy all the time, being tired or in pain can make anyone more easily angered. Some head injuries can lead to changes in ability to control emotions or behavior (be sure to ask your child’s doctor about what to expect).
quizResults.q11body2: Is irritability making it hard for your child to get along with family or friends? Is this a big change in your child’s usual personality?
quizResults.q12title: Has trouble paying attention to things, since the injury
quizResults.q12body1: When we are under a lot of stress, feel really jumpy or on guard, or have thoughts of what happened popping into mind, it can be hard to pay attention at times. Some head injuries can lead to concentration problems (be sure to ask your child’s doctor about what to expect).
quizResults.q12body2: Is difficulty concentrating getting in the way of schoolwork, or your child’s ability to take part in other activities or sports?
quizResults.q13title: Has trouble falling or staying asleep, since the injury
quizResults.q13body1: Some sleep problems after an injury are a temporary reaction to disruptions in your child’s schedule and routines. But sleep problems can be made worse by pain from the injury, or by worries and thoughts that make it hard to relax.
quizResults.q13body2: Is your child having a hard time falling asleep or staying asleep many nights? Is your child afraid to sleep alone?
quizResults.q14title: Is still having pain or discomfort
quizResults.q14body1: Most injured children have pain, at least at first. Pain cannot always be managed completely, but doctors do their best to get it under control as soon as possible.
quizResults.q14body2: Your child may tell you they are in pain, or you might see the effects of pain in their behavior. Pain can make it harder to sleep and harder to concentrate. Follow up may be needed if your child’s pain is getting worse or if it interferes with getting a good night’s sleep or paying attention in school.
quizResults.q15title: Has had other behavior changes since the injury
quizResults.q15body1: Many times behavior changes are temporary reactions to injury-related stresses and to normal life being turned “upside down”, at least for while. Frustrations or worries can lead to clingy or angry behaviors. Some head injuries can also lead to behavior changes (be sure to ask your child’s doctor about what to expect).
quizResults.q15body2: Are behavior changes making it harder for your child to get along with people or to get back to regular activities? Have these changes lasted for more than a few weeks?
quizResults.q16title: Is having trouble with returning to school or other activities
quizResults.q16body1: Returning to school may require physical accommodations (such as getting around on crutches). Stress and worry can sometimes make it harder to concentrate on schoolwork. And after an injury, there may be changes (at least for a while) in your child’s ability to participate in sports and other activities they enjoy.
quizResults.q16body2: Are you worried about how things will go when your child returns to school? Is your child having trouble keeping up with schoolwork? Is your child very upset about missing out on sports or other activities because of the injury?
quizResults.q17title: Brothers or sisters are upset or worried
quizResults.q17body1: Injury can affect the whole family. When a child is hurt or in the hospital, brothers and sisters may be worried, frightened, or even angry. It’s hard for parents to meet everyone’s needs at the same time.
quizResults.q17body2: You may notice that your other children are missing your attention, or that they are upset or worried.
quizResults.q18title: You (parent) are stressed or worried yourself
quizResults.q18body1: After your child is injured, there are lots of things that you as a parent have to cope with. It’s normal for parents to feel stress and to be concerned about the future. Many parents also have some traumatic stress reactions in the first few weeks. If these don’t get better in a month or so, they may signal a problem that needs attention.
quizResults.q18body2: Have these feelings lasted for more than a month? Are worries about your child keeping you from being able to concentrate, get enough sleep, or get back to work or other activities?

link.text: A Parent’s Guide to Building Resilience in Children and Teens: Giving Your Child Roots and Wings
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy A Parent’s Guide to Building Resilience in Children and Teens: Giving Your Child Roots and Wings
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy A Parent’s Guide to Building Resilience in Children and Teens: Giving Your Child Roots and Wings

content.contentText: Today’s children face a great deal of stress — academic performance, heavy scheduling, high achievement standards, media messages, peer pressures, family tension.  Without healthier solutions, they often cope by talking back, giving up, or indulging in unhealthy behaviors. Show your child how to bounce back — and THRIVE — with coping strategies from one of the nation’s foremost experts in adolescent medicine.

link.text: Freeing Your Child from Anxiety: Powerful, Practical Solutions to Overcome Your Child's Fears, Worries and Phobias
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy Freeing Your Child from Anxiety: Powerful, Practical Solutions to Overcome Your Child's Fears, Worries and Phobias
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy Freeing Your Child from Anxiety: Powerful, Practical Solutions to Overcome Your Child's Fears, Worries and Phobias

content.contentText: Anxiety is the number one mental health problem facing young people today.  Childhood should be a happy and carefree time, yet more and more children today are exhibiting symptoms of anxiety, from bedwetting and clinginess to frequent stomach aches, nightmares, and even refusing to go to school. Parents everywhere want to know: All children have fears, but how much is normal? How can you know when a stress has crossed over into a full-blown anxiety disorder? Most parents don’t know how to recognize when there is a real problem and how to deal with it when there is.

link.text: Children and Trauma: A Guide for Parents and Professionals
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy Children and Trauma: A Guide for Parents and Professionals
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy Children and Trauma: A Guide for Parents and Professionals

content.contentText: Childhood traumas range widely in their severity and impact.  A car accident, an earthquake or flood, being attacked by a dog, undergoing a frightening medical treatment? All are distinctly different events yet all provoke common symptoms of psychological trauma.  These symptoms may include fearfulness, nightmares, and dramatic behavioral or personality changes. And parental anxiety over changes in a child can, in turn, complicate the healing process.

link.text: When I Feel Scared (The Way I Feel Books)
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy When I Feel Scared (The Way I Feel Books)
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy When I Feel Scared (The Way I Feel Books)

content.contentText: Children will recognize similar experiences in their own lives as this little bear describes feeling scared when he has a bad dream or his mother goes away.  Eventually our hero realizes that it's OK to be scared sometimes, and there are ways he can help himself when he's frightened.

link.text: What to Do When You're Sad & Lonely: A Guide for Kids
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy What to Do When You're Sad & Lonely: A Guide for Kids
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy What to Do When You're Sad & Lonely: A Guide for Kids

content.contentText: All kids feel sad and lonely sometimes. Growing numbers of children are living with depression, a disease often mistaken for sadness.  This reassuring book offers strategies and tips kids can use to beat the blues and blahs, get a handle on their feelings, make and keep friends, and enjoy their time alone.  The second part focuses on depression, bipolar disorder, grief, and other problems too big for kids to handle on their own, and describes what it’s like to go to counseling.  Includes a Note to Grown-ups and a list of resources.

link.text: What to Do What You’re Scared and Worried: A Guide for Kids
link.accessibilityHint: Navigates to Amazon to buy What to Do What You’re Scared and Worried: A Guide for Kids
link.accessibilityLabel: Click here to visit Amazon to buy What to Do What You’re Scared and Worried: A Guide for Kids

content.contentText: From a dread of spiders to panic attacks, kids have worries and fears, just like adults.  This is a book kids can turn to when they need advice, reassurance, and ideas.  They’ll find out where fears and worries come from, practice Fear Chasers and Worry Erasers, and learn to seek help for hard-to-handle fears they can’t manage on their own.
